Thus have I heard: Once, the Buddha was traveling with five hundred Å›ramaá¹‡as in Vá¹›ji,
and he sat under a tree outside Drum Vehicle City.
There was a wealthy and virtuous brahmin named PÄrÄÅ›arya, who was well-versed in the scriptures, astronomy, and divination, and could answer any question.
He had five hundred disciples, and the foremost among them was named AmbÄá¹­á¹­ha.
AmbÄá¹­á¹­ha asked his teacher:
Now there is a Buddha who has come. People praise his virtues, saying his name covers heaven and earth. I do not know who this person is.
PÄrÄÅ›arya said:
I have heard that he is the prince of the king of the ÅšÄkya clan. He has no teacher and has composed scriptures and teachings on his own.
AmbÄá¹­á¹­ha said:
If he has no teacher, how can his reputation be so great?
Moreover, princes are often arrogant, licentious, and fond of pleasure. How could he possibly travel on foot, lower his aspirations, beg for food, and teach others tirelessly?
Is he perhaps a true person?
I wish the teacher would go and observe his virtue and conduct.
Fei Zhi said:
No, I am a worldly aristocrat, wise and talented, while he is newly emerged. It is fitting for him to come and pay respects to me, I should not go to him.
Avataka said:

I have heard that even the Heavenly Emperor and the Seventh Brahma have come down to serve him. His disciples have all attained the five supernatural powers, can fly with lightness, see far and hear clearly, know the intentions of others, and where they came from in their previous lives and where they will go after death.
He is truly a heavenly teacher, why would he come to pay respects?
Fei Zhi said:ğŸ”½If he is truly a sage, he will not come to pay respects to me. If he is not a sage, he will come to pay respects to me. I will go and observe him.

The sutra says that when a king's son is born with thirty-two marks, he will immediately become a wheel-turning king, rule the four continents, and naturally possess seven treasures: a golden wheel treasure, a white elephant treasure, a dark horse treasure, a jade woman treasure, a divine pearl treasure, a steward treasure, and a wise general treasure. He will have a thousand sons, all of whom are talented, wise, and brave, with each one equal to a thousand men. His weapons will not be used, and his world will be peaceful.
If he abandons the kingdom, he will naturally become a buddha, using non-action as his teaching, liberating people and enabling them to attain the Way.
Could he be the one?
You should go and observe.
If he has these marks, he must be the Buddha. I will serve him.
Upagupta said:
I wish to go with like-minded companions.
The teacher said:
Excellent.
He then went with five hundred disciples, all dismounting and bowing to the Buddha.
The Buddha asked them to take their seats, and all five hundred people sat down. Only Avataka hovered to the left and right, slightly observing the Buddha's appearance.
The Buddha knew his thoughts and also rose to walk side by side with him. When Avataka stopped, the Buddha also stopped.
When Avataka sat down, the Buddha also sat down.
Avataka then asked the Buddha, saying:
What kind of path is the fundamental matter?
What is the significance of shaving the beard and hair, wearing a kasaya robe, and carrying a bowl?
The Buddha said:
Since I sought the Way, passing through many generations for a long time, it cannot be described.
I have always served the Buddhas, practicing the bodhisattva path, and the teachers and friends I have served are countless.
Shaving the beard and hair is for lifelong precepts, abandoning greed and love, and having no more adornments.
It causes people not to desire oneself, and oneself also does not desire others.
The kasaya Dharma robe is a sign of the ancient sages, explaining away the knots of defilements, having no more worldly thoughts.
The bowl is a proper vessel, suitable for practitioners to use, to restrain the body and reduce desires, and not to accept what is not meaningful.
These are all images of unconditioned purity.
Now that I have become a Buddha, the teacher of the world, I will let you ask freely, do not hesitate.
Apu said:
The teacher we serve, PÅ«raá¹‡a KÄÅ›yapa, is wise from generation to generation, and his fame reaches far. Moreover, he is of the Brahmin caste, especially superior to other people.
Although the most noble in the world may be kings, there are also those who are not benevolent, but our caste alone does not like killing.
The Buddha said:
I originally sought the unsurpassed true path of Buddhahood because of my aversion to killing.
You Brahmins only value benevolence with your mouths. Although your hands do not kill, your minds all have killing.
Now I am a Buddha, with a pure body, speech, and mind, and do not kill anything.
It is because people in the world all like killing that I teach them benevolence and righteousness.
Apu asked:
Now the Buddha has abandoned his wife and children, cutting off his lineage, which is not as good as my teacher, who continues the lineage from generation to generation.
The Buddha said:

The appearances of people in the world are fundamentally different. In their past lives, all people were once my children, and I was also once the child of all people. We will inevitably part, and kinship is impermanent. Sometimes enemies become close relatives, and sometimes relatives become enemies again. The combination and separation of causes and conditions are all like illusions.

Parents, wife, and children are not my close relatives, and I also do not belong to them. People in the world only create offenses and evils because of 'this is mine' and 'this is not mine,' and later they will suffer.
In my ancient past, I was once a kshatriya king named Drumasanthaka. I had four sons, the first named Ukkaccha, the second named Canda, the third named Dhataraá¹­á¹­ha, and the fourth named Sudatta.

The king had not yet passed away, but the four sons were vying for the throne. The king, hearing of the four sons' contention, thought it would lead to the slaughter of the people. He then abdicated and left eastwards, thinking to himself as he went:

Life is short, and only without worries can one live long. Now, I became king, wishing to have an heir. Having already had sons, they now want to fight each other. Having an heir like this, what benefit is it to people?
I cannot bear to see it, fearing the killing of the innocent. I shall simply abandon my family and become a monk.
He then entered the mountains to the north and stayed in the grass hut of the ascetic KÄÅ›yapa.
There was also the ascetic MaudgalyÄyana. The king asked him about his origins:
Why did you study the Way?
MaudgalyÄyana said:
I took a wife but had no children. My face was shameful before the families. Therefore, I became a monk.
The king said:
How strange!
I am the king of a country, with four sons. Before my body has died, my sons have caused chaos in the country. I cannot bear to see this, so I have become a monk.
Moluo's mind was enlightened, and he then diligently practiced.
In this way, Abat, even if your son is wise, when the father is old and sick and dies, the son cannot prevent it.
When alive, if one does evil, after death one enters hell, and the son cannot take one's place.
For this reason, I always use the compassionate mind to save and help people and things. When the Way is accomplished and I become a Buddha, I will deliver the world.
Abat said:
The Buddha is difficult to encounter.
There are four kinds of people in the world today: gentlemen, Brahmins, farmers, and craftsmen. Only my Brahmin caste is true and noble.
The other three groups all serve my caste.
The Buddha said:
If your caste is truly noble, if your wife has no son and a maid gives birth to a boy, would you raise him?ğŸ”½He said:
No, I would not.
You should raise it.
Now your grandmother has taken a slave's son as her heir, can this be truly noble?
Abat was silent, and the five hundred disciples all stood up and said:
Gautama Shakra, why do you slander our kind?
Abat is also able to debate with you.
The Buddha said:
All be silent.
If he has talent and wisdom, he will be able to debate himself.
The Buddha asked his ancestor, but he did not respond up to three times.
The Vajra Warrior raised his great pestle and said:
The Buddha has asked you again, why do you not respond?
Abat was afraid and said:
It is truly as the Buddha says.
The five hundred people said:
The Buddha's holy wisdom is clear. Abat's mother is a slave of the Shakyas.
From now on, we request not to respect her anymore.
The Buddha said:
No, it is not so.
In the world, a mother may be lowly, but her son may be wise and noble. Abatthama is a wise person, and should not be disparaged.
If a Brahmin marries a Kshatriya woman and they have a son who grows up, should he study his father's way or his mother's way?
They all said:
He should study his father's way.
The Buddha said:
In this way, what harm is there if the mother is lowly?
If the son grows up, becomes knowledgeable, and surpasses his father in conduct, you should respect him.
If a Brahmin woman becomes a Kshatriya's wife and they have a son who grows up, knowing that his mother's family is wise, but he is unwilling to study,
and instead follows his father's way of hunting and killing, should you respect him?
They all said:
We would not respect him.
The Buddha said:
In this way, why ask about the mother?
If Abatthama has a son who is even wiser and more outstanding than him, what will you do?
They all said:
We will seat him at the head of the row.
If both parents are of the Brahmin caste, but the child is unfilial and lacks propriety, what should be done?
They all said:
He should be seated below.
The Buddha said:
Is it so that nobility is permanent?
If a Brahmin child kills, steals, or breaks the law, will the authorities arrest him?
He said:
They should arrest him.
Why don't you resist and say:
'My caste is noble, you should not arrest me?'
He said:
Since he has committed a crime, how can he speak of his caste!
The Buddha said:
Now I am the Buddha, teaching the people benevolence and filial piety, instructing them with right words, to remove desire, anger, and delusion.
Those who have the attitude of permanence and do evil, I will teach them to refrain from killing, stealing, sexual misconduct, false speech, drinking alcohol, and worshipping in deviant ways.
If a person commits evil in the past, they will suffer the consequences in the body. Sacrificing and killing to worship heaven is a grave mistake that does not bring any benefit.
Moreover, the will of heaven is pure benevolence. How can it eat the food of humans?
Those with virtue receive blessings, not killing for the sake of blessings.
Therefore, the wise and intelligent rulers of the world, upon hearing the Buddhist precepts, all cut off [killing] themselves and vow not to do evil.
Those who uphold the precepts and die have their spiritual essence ascend to heaven;
If one can be sincere and pure in mind, one can attain the four paths of Å›ramaá¹‡as:
1. Stream-enterer, 2. Once-returner, 3. Non-returner, 4. Arhat.
Moreover, although the kings of the world may rule with the desire for fairness, they still levy taxes on the people, and their greedy thoughts are not eliminated.
Now I have become a Buddha, completely causing the world to be free from desires and attain the path of non-action.

Since I sought the Way, my kalpas have been countless. Every time I was born, I had a vow to abandon desires and cultivate the path of asceticism, without preference or rejection. Among the wise and virtuous gentlemen of the world, none did not uphold the Buddha's sutras and precepts. Those who did not follow them later all had regrets.

Those who could control their minds and have no further greed and desires, then cut off the path of birth, death, sorrow, and crying, and do not pursue each other with affection, and can escape suffering.
The world is impermanent, people are like water bubbles, forming and decaying, unable to preserve themselves.
The Buddha asked A-ba-tuo:
What does your teacher teach and admonish?
He replied:
The teacher admonishes not to kill people or cows, not to steal gold and silver, not to have sex with the teacher's wife or the disciple's wife, and not to drink alcohol.
At the age of forty-eight, one may then marry a wife.
My teacher teaches people to observe these eight precepts.
I do not yet know the Buddha's precepts, what is their meaning?
The Buddha said:
Those who wish to listen, listen.
If a son of a good family himself confesses and delights in the Buddha's precepts, I will bestow the precepts according to his ability.
Those who wish to practice the path while living at home are called lay followers. They should uphold five precepts:
First, do not kill birds, beasts, or any wriggling creatures, do not harm them, and consider others as you would yourself, do not use knives or clubs, think of kindness, and do not speak of killing.

Second, do not steal or covet other people's wealth, do not cheat with weights, measures, or scales, even by the smallest amount, do not infringe upon others, keep your thoughts in line with righteousness, and do not speak of taking things.

Third, do not engage in sexual misconduct with others' wives, do not look at beautiful colors, do not listen to beautiful music, cultivate propriety and prohibitions in your mind, and do not speak of improper things.
Fourth, do not speak falsely or slander others' faults;
Speak only when necessary, and let your words be sincere and trustworthy;
Do not let your thoughts be lax, and do not speak of others' faults or praise yourself.
Fifth, do not drink alcohol.
Even if one indulges in drinking, one should not have a good taste for it, and one's mouth should not savor it. Alcohol has thirty-six faults, so one should not encourage others to drink.
This is called the precepts of a faithful layman for me.
The Buddha said:
I do not call people, but people come to me and request to receive the precepts respectfully, spread the teachings, abandon evil and do good.
The wise and intelligent in the world who wish to become monks, I always ask them first, what has awakened them?
As a son, one should be filial and respectful, and make it a priority to provide for one's parents.
If one wishes to practice the Way, one should repay one's parents.

If one's parents give their permission, then I will explain the precepts of a monk, which number two hundred and fifty, and one should be pure for life. One should not be unable to continue halfway and lose the kindness of offerings.
If someone deliberately invites and their faith does not waver, and they are able to uphold the precepts, then I will give them the precepts.

The precepts of Å›ramaá¹‡as take compassion and kindness as their basis. They should not harm or kill any living creature. They should have sympathy for people, surpassing that for their own children;
They should not bring lawsuits against others, seeking justice from them;
They should always remember the kindness of their parents and teachers, diligently seek the Way, and wish to deliver their parents.
Åšramaá¹‡as should not greedily deceive and falsely take people's wealth. When seeing various treasures, they should regard them as filth;

If others give them things, they should not accept them. If they do accept them, they should not keep them, but distribute them to the poor. They should always explain to people the virtue of non-greed.
Åšramaá¹‡as should not have wives or continue their lineages. They should keep women at a distance and restrain their emotions;

When walking and seeing beautiful colors, they should not turn their eyes to look at them. They should regard older women as their mothers, and younger women as their sisters. If their minds do not stop, they should contemplate the impurity of the body to ward off lustful thoughts;
The arising of birth and death is all due to delusion and attachment.
Åšramaá¹‡as should not speak falsely, frivolously, or slander others' faults. What they see and hear should be in accordance with reality. They should not transmit unrighteous things;
Reconciling disputes means speaking well of both sides;
Speaking slowly and only what is correct, without revealing others' private matters.
Monks should not sing, dance, play, or discuss entertainers. They should diligently contemplate and learn new things while reviewing the old.

What monks say must be in accordance with the Dharma. They should not create things that have not been heard. They should recite the sutras morning and night without error. They should diligently practice the essentials of the path to eliminate various defilements, and explain the Dharma to others with a mind in accord with the meaning.
Monks should not lie on comfortable beds, wear colorful clothes, eat without flavor, or use gold, silver, lacquerware. They should only use earthenware and iron bowls.
Monks should not drink alcohol, crave meat, or think of tasting flavors. They should not take alcohol as medicine or visit liquor stores.
Monks should not apply flowers and fragrances to their bodies or burn incense on their clothes. They should think of upholding the precepts.
Åšramaá¹‡as should not buy or own slaves, or hire servants, and should not accept them even if offered.
Åšramaá¹‡as should not keep the six domestic animals, carriages, or ride horses to indulge their hearts and desires.
Åšramaá¹‡as should not store rice and grain, but beg for food every morning, not going to more than seven households;
if they do not get anything at one household, they go to a second household, and if they do not get anything after going to seven households, they should just drink water.
When Å›ramaá¹‡as enter a village, they should be like birds eating, flying away when full, without looking back at the rest;
if they do not get food, their minds should not be upset.
Åšramaá¹‡as abandon their homes and do not harbor thoughts of comfort, not longing for fine dwellings, but only for mountains, forests, and under trees.
Åšramaá¹‡as should not engage in commerce to seek profit, thinking about what is valuable and what is cheap here and there.
Åšramaá¹‡as should not have fields, houses, or gardens, nor should they plow and plant crops, thinking of the joy of farming.
Åšramaá¹‡as should not discuss pleasant lands, water, fragrances, or flowers, but single-mindedly contemplate the Way and should not think of other things.
Åšramaá¹‡as should not discuss the good and bad of the country, cities, towns, or villages, or have any sense of superiority or inferiority.
Åšramaá¹‡as should not comment on the foundations of their fellow practitioners' livelihoods, fields, houses, grain, food, or clothing, saying one has this or that does not have it.
Åšramaá¹‡as should not lie down and talk or eat and speak, and should not preemptively know the state's political affairs, military strategies, or whether to attack or withdraw.
Åšramaá¹‡as should not discuss their clothing, food, delicacies, or coarse spring water, whether it is good or bad.
Åšramaá¹‡as should not discuss the good or bad appearances of various animals;
this is the talk of foolish people, not the speech of the Dharma.
Åšramaá¹‡as should not claim to understand the scriptures themselves, saying that others do not understand, and praise themselves as wise, nor should they be arrogant.
When Å›ramaá¹‡as expound the Dharma, they should not say that my scriptures are beneficial while yours are obstructive, or that my precepts and practices are pure while yours are defiled;
One should not say, My teacher is enlightened, but your teacher is not enlightened.
The Buddha's scriptures are unified and their return is non-dual. With a lofty ambition, one should not tolerate slander or praise.
One should not say, My family is of high status, but your family is poor and humble.
One should not boast that one has debated with so-and-so and that one was not inferior.

Monks should not compare each other's good beds, tables, bedding, pillows, and bedding, or say that someone has poor clothes. One should not look in a mirror, groom one's beard, or think of fine and smooth [sensations].
One should not watch wealthy people fighting with lowly people or animals fighting.
One should not imitate them by striking each other with one's hands.
One should not play go, chess, or other games, lie down lazily, scheme about food, or think of going to a certain place or prefecture and returning from there, calculating the distance.
One should not practice medicine for men, women, cows, or horses.
One should not teach people to vomit or not vomit.
One should not practice playing with weapons, shooting marbles, or throwing games.
Do not study the characteristics of men and women, the poor and the rich, the noble and the humble, with characteristics or without characteristics, and the appearance of the six domestic animals;
Do not engage in divination to predict droughts, floods, natural disasters, and the abundance or scarcity of the year.

Monks should not look up at the calendar, calculate the movements of the sun and moon, eclipses, falling stars, or strange phenomena, the collapse of mountains, earthquakes, or the wind and rain of the year, and should not know anything about them.

Monks should not eat after noon. Their clothing and food should be coarse and simple, and they should not complain. Their alms bowl should always be placed under their left armpit. Wherever they go, they should not worry about hunger or cold. Their body should always be with their alms bowl, like a bird with wings;
Their mouth should not eat indiscriminately. The six senses should always be upright. They should be ashamed of their ambitions not rising and not resent the suffering of their bodies;
They should wish to be in the sutras and precepts. Their eyes should not gaze at colors, and their ears, nose, mouth, and body should not be moved by what is better or worse.

He regulates his food to keep his body neither hungry nor full, and when sleeping he seeks only to rest his body and does not sleep for long. He upholds his lofty and pure will, always abiding in nirvana.
It is like a filial son whose parents have passed away early. He grieves and thinks of them, not forgetting them for a moment.

This is how my Å›ramaá¹‡as guard their will and practice the Way. When sitting, they contemplate in meditation; when rising, they chant and recite. They diligently strive in wakefulness and sleep, not neglecting the precepts.
This is being a disciple of the Buddha.
The Buddha told Ä€bhibhÄá¹£a:
Such precepts number two hundred and fifty, but I have only roughly explained them now.
Åšramaá¹‡as restrain their minds and do not let them be unrestrained. Dwelling in a quiet place, they distance themselves from lust, anger, and delusion, and seek wisdom.

They always use the mind of compassion to pity all under heaven. They abandon the attitudes of sleep, lying down, and craving desire. Single-mindedly believing in the Dharma, they no longer have doubts, and then attain arhatship.

Arhats are those who have attained true realization. It is like a person who has always been poor and in debt, but through business endeavors, they earn profits and return home, finally feeling joyful.
There are also criminals who have been imprisoned for a long time, but a good person uses skillful means to help them escape.
It is also like slaves and servants becoming free commoners, or a person who has been sick for many years finally recovering through medical treatment.
It is also like a merchant who has traveled through difficult and dangerous paths and returns with a heavy load of goods.
These five parables - people all feel joyful, and I, a Å›ramaá¹‡a, am also like this.
I think to myself that I have been bound by birth and death for a long time, and the suffering of the five aggregates is immeasurable. Now I have attained liberation.
What are the five aggregates?
First, form; second, sensation; third, perception; fourth, mental formations; fifth, consciousness.
These five cover people and prevent them from seeing the Way.
The Å›ramaá¹‡a thinks to himself, realizing impermanence, that the body is not his body, and his foolish and ignorant mind is unattached. The aggregate of form is eliminated, which is the first joy;

The Å›ramaá¹‡a contemplates and sees the impurities of the five viscera in his own body. The intention of greed and desire is understood, and there is no duality of good and evil. The aggregate of pain has been eliminated, which is the second joy.

The Å›ramaá¹‡a contemplates with utmost sincerity, sees the suffering of affection and love, does not engage in the practice of defilements, and has no intention of seeking pleasure again. The aggregate of perception has been eliminated, which is the third joy.

The Å›ramaá¹‡a contemplates, with the purity of body, speech, and mind, no longer having joy or anger, with a tranquil and concentrated mind, not arising or engaging in action. The aggregate of mental formations has been eliminated, which is the fourth joy.

The Å›ramaá¹‡a thinks to himself, having attained the pure teachings of the Buddha, cutting off all conditioned arising, with the extinction of delusion and desire, the aggregate of consciousness has been eliminated, which is the fifth joy.
The Buddha told Ä€pÄlan:
We Å›ramaá¹‡as abandon desires, practice the scriptures and precepts, and cut off birth and death. Then in this world, there is no more worry, crying, or attachment to each other.
I do not crave others, and others do not crave me.
But I, with the compassion of the Way, have thoughts for all, wishing to cause them to be liberated.
For a person to practice the Way, it is suffering for only one lifetime.
For one who does not practice the Way, the suffering is even longer.
It is like a person bathing, only able to be externally clean, with the defilements of the mind not removed;
One who attains arhatship has all evil completely removed.

The mind of an ordinary person is like a stone on the ground, not melting under the sun's heat, not released by the rain's moisture, not moved by the wind's blowing. Emerging from the ordinary and vulgar, attaining the ultimate Way, the mind and thoughts have already become cold, with no further heat or desire.
It is like a lotus flower emerging from muddy water, with the roots and leaves always cool, with dust and water not adhering.
The Å›ramaá¹‡a thinks to himself:
Parents raise their child, the kindness reaching only one lifetime, but the Buddha opens up the world, enabling people to attain the Way.
He sees for himself the beginning and end of the five destinies of birth and death, knows the lifespan of people, and his will has already become upright.
What he does is unrestrained, wishing to ascend to heaven he ascends, to enter the ocean he enters.
It is like using fragrant water to bathe a dead person, it cannot make them fragrant. Teaching an evil person to be good, cannot necessarily make them good.
If a person's mind is evil, their body and speech will both be evil.
The non-Buddhists say, Just indulge in desires, there is no true path.
When a practitioner hears this, they should never respond.
Knowing the ordinary person's mind, thoughts and views are all inverted. The foolish do not understand the Way, taking the correct as wrong, not distinguishing the true from the false.
The sages pity them and therefore add loving-kindness. The Å›ramaá¹‡a holds the mind like a person wearing new clothes, sitting and rising carefully, not wanting to stain them.
Therefore, the one who upholds the precepts always struggles with the mind, even if a hundred evils come, they will never listen or accept them.
Parents give birth to a child, when young they transform them with the Way, when grown they commit crimes and die, they cannot blame their relatives.
It is like sitting on a bed with wood but no rope, one cannot sit.
If a child has no wise teacher, they will not attain the Way either. Such is the Confucian scholar.
In my past lives, I served many sages, and what I received was not ordinary, all of them were non-action teachers.

Those who attained arhatship can explain for themselves, in such and such a place they attained the stage of stream-entry, in such and such a place they attained the stage of once-returning and non-returning, up to the state of arhatship, completely liberated, no longer subject to birth and death.
Fully knowing the vastness, like seeing a beautiful painting with the five colors distinct.
Seeing that all people in the world have the tendencies of the three poisons, arrogance, negligence, and craving for flavors.
Knowing that one is already liberated, one no longer craves rebirth in the heavens, nor delights in the human realm.
But thinking of sentient beings, wishing to liberate them.
Ordinary people who have not heard this should carefully study and accept it, like holding colored silk to string lapis lazuli beads, with the five colors all appearing.

The eyes of the Way see where people's souls come from when born and where they go after death, knowing that the souls of some die and fall into hell, some fall into the animal realm, some fall into the realm of ghosts and spirits, some enter human form, and some die and ascend to heaven.

When the Way is accomplished, one knows for oneself that these five places have been cut off, and one's wishes have been fulfilled. One views the body as earth, and allows others to take it and break it apart.
This clarifies the true and false, like entering clear water where all the sand, gravel, and jewels are seen.
Foreknowing the world, one person is worth a hundred, and a hundred people are worth one.
Why is this so?
When one person has a child, it passes to the great-great-grandchild, flourishing to become a hundred.

Sometimes a hundred people die and are left empty, with only one remaining Å›ramaá¹‡a who has attained the Way, fully seeing good and evil, knowing which people who die will be reborn in the good realms, and also knowing which people will fall into the evil realms.
One sees the number of the four qi in one's own body and knows the lifespan, suffering, happiness, and length of life of others.

Originally, from the state of non-illumination, mental consciousness becomes activity, and activity receives name and form, merely relying on conditions, being born in the mother's womb, worrying about each other, the parents say my child, the child says my parents, the spirit transmigrates and does not recognize itself.
Those with good past lives are reborn as humans, then wealthy, noble, and long-lived;
Those with unwholesomeness suffer short lives, each due to their own karma.
Heaven, earth, humans, and things, all depend on the four qi:
Earth, water, fire, and wind.

In the human body, the strong is earth, the harmonious and moist is water, the warm heat is fire, and the breath is wind. Life borrows and uses this, and upon death, it returns to its origin. Calculating its beginning and end, each is for others. Ordinary people are unaware.
Between heaven and earth, the living are like a dream. Life and wealth are extremely short, and one dies in turmoil.
It is like the wind blowing on the sea, with waves chasing each other. Birth and death are also like this, coming and going without rest.
Åšramaá¹‡as who attain the Way all know the beginning and end of the formation and destruction of heaven and earth, and the events of one kalpa, the bodies they have gone through.
They also know the events of the distant, countless kalpas, and thus know that the immortals who attain the Way in the world cannot surpass the Buddha.

They know that their own intentions originally had myriad aspects, but now they have accomplished one thing. They always feel pity for the masses, who are confused by greed and desire, and intoxicated by lust, anger, and delusion, which disturb their chests. They may create affection and love, but do not know this essential truth.
Those who attain the Way can see through it.
It is like a person looking in a mirror, flying unimpeded, passing through stone walls.
They can ascend to Mount Sumeru and touch the sun and moon with their hands;
They can emit water and fire separately from their bodies;
